I like to tap the side of the strainer to get even more water out. The berries will reduce in volume and you&#8217;ll be left with about 1 cup of thawed berries.", "name": "Thaw the Berries", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/mixed-berry-muffins-with-sugary-tops#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently fold the berries into the muffin batter. If using extra firm high protein tofu, it helps to cut it in half again horizontally. Press the water out of the tofu by wrapping it in paper towels and setting a few heavy books on top of it. Let it stay like that for a few minutes while you prep the sauce.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the sauce ingredients together.\u00a0", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take each piece of tofu and gently pull it into small chunks with your hands (this just gives the tofu pieces a unique shape and texture that holds onto the sauce really well). Place the chunks in a bowl. Toss with soy sauce and a teaspoon or two of olive oil; then sprinkle with cornstarch and give it a few gentle tosses to coat.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Before your start browning your tofu, cook your rice according to package directions and start your green beans! Steam, microwave, saut\u00e8 &#8211; whatever your preferred green bean method is.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a nonstick skillet over medium high heat, heat the olive oil and then add the cornstarched tofu. Leave it undisturbed for a few minutes on each side, letting it get really nice and brown and crispy &#8211; this can take 10-15 minutes. Flip and repeat until the whole batch is browned and crispy.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Finally, add the sauce to the tofu and remove from heat &#8211; the pan will still be hot, so it&#8217;ll be sizzly and smell really good from the garlic. The sauce will coat the tofu right away. *heart eyes*", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/sesame-apricot-tofu#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Top with the chives and/or cilantro and sesame oil. Pour that into your soup as you heat it on a very low simmer. Keep the lid off and stir it in. The cornstarch will thicken it and the longer it simmers the thicker it will get, since the steam you see is water leaving the soup. You can skip the cornstarch step if you don't have any, but it will just take 10x longer. Each vinegar imparts its unique flavor profile, which will affect the overall taste of the sauce.\r\n\r\n    Rice vinegar: It is a mild, slightly sweet vinegar made from fermented rice. This vinegar has a subtle, delicate flavor, which can brighten the peanut sauce without overpowering it. Using rice vinegar in the recipe will result in a lighter, more balanced sauce that allows the peanut flavor to shine through.\r\n\r\n    Chinese black vinegar: This vinegar, also known as Chinkiang vinegar, is made from fermented grains such as rice, wheat, and millet. It has a complex, rich, and slightly smoky flavor. Using Chinese black vinegar in the peanut sauce will result in a deeper, more robust flavor profile with a hint of smokiness.\r\n\r\n    Worcestershire sauce: This is a fermented sauce made from ingredients like vinegar, molasses, sugar, salt, anchovies, tamarind extract, and various spices. It has a tangy, savory, and slightly sweet taste with a hint of umami. Using Worcestershire sauce in place of Chinese black vinegar will also result in a more robust sauce, but with a different flavor profile, adding a unique savory and tangy twist to the peanut sauce.\r\n\r\nIn summary, using rice vinegar will give you a lighter, more delicate peanut sauce, while using Chinese black vinegar or Worcestershire sauce will result in a bolder, more complex sauce with different flavor nuances. Your choice should depend on your personal taste preferences and the specific dish you're using the sauce for."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Alia @ Everyday Easy Eats"}, "datePublished": "2019-05-13", "reviewBody": "Oh my this peanut sauce looks delicious! Transfer to a bowl and add the honey or maple syrup, coconut oil, and vanilla. Stir until a thick paste forms.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/dark-chocolate-coconut-bites#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your hands, squeeze the mixture into about 18 small balls. I found that rolling was difficult because they weren&#8217;t sticky enough, but I was able to shape them into balls by first squeezing them in my palm a few times (you&#8217;ll get some oil on your hands), and then gently shaping it from an oval into a round ball. Place the coconut balls in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes or until firm. I could tell that mine were ready because there was a small white ring of solidified coconut oil around the base of each ball.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/dark-chocolate-coconut-bites#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chocolate slowly and gently until smooth and spreadable. We don&#8217;t have a microwave, so I had the best results melting this in a stainless steel bowl placed in a hot oven for about 10 minutes.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/dark-chocolate-coconut-bites#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lay out a sheet of wax paper. Using two forks, roll each coconut ball in the chocolate until completely covered. Scoop the ball out with the fork and let the extra chocolate drip off the fork. Gently nudge the chocolate covered ball onto wax paper and chill until the chocolate has hardened. To freeze before cooking, place the formed patties on a parchment-lined baking sheet and freeze them for 6-8 hours - this ensures they won't stick together. Then put them in an airtight container and you're good to go. To freeze after cooking, just place in an airtight container once they've cooled. And it&#8217;s really really helpful to let the bread cool before cutting into it, otherwise it has a tendency to sink down where you cut it. Simple and over-the-top delicious.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "skillet cookie, deep dish cookie, deep dish chocolate chip cookie", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/deep-dish-cookies-square-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/deep-dish-cookies-square-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/deep-dish-cookies-square-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/deep-dish-cookies-square.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/deep-dish-chocolate-chip-cookie-with-caramel-sea-salt", "recipeIngredient": ["2 sticks (16 tablespoons) butter", "1 cup granulated sugar", "1/2 cup packed brown sugar", "2 teaspoons vanilla", "2 tablespoons real maple syrup", "2 eggs", "2 3/4 cup flour", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup chocolate chunks (I chopped up a large piece of Scharffen Berger chocolate &#8211; yum)", "1/2 cup milk chocolate chips", "1/2 cup caramel pieces (affiliate link)", "3 tablespoons heavy whipping cream", "coarse sea salt to taste"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350 degree. Soften the\u00a08 tablespoons butter in the microwave for 30 seconds or until partially melted. Add the vanilla and maple syrup and mix again until smooth. Add the eggs; beat slowly until incorporated. Add the flour, baking soda, and salt (sometimes it helps to add the flour in batches). Mix until a smooth dough forms. The dough should feel dry to the touch &#8211; if it sticks to your hands, add a few more tablespoons of flour. I generally try to err on the side of more flour. Stir in the chocolate chips and chocolate chunks. Melt the caramel pieces and heavy cream in the microwave for 2 minutes. Stir well until melted and smooth.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/deep-dish-chocolate-chip-cookie-with-caramel-sea-salt#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Press half of the dough mixture into a 9-inch or larger cast iron skillet lined with parchment paper. (affiliate link) Pour the caramel over the dough and smooth with a spoon. Cover with another layer of cookie dough. Bake for 15-25 minutes (see notes). Cut the reserved half onion into thin slices and add to the pan. Caramelize/fry onion until golden brown and sweet tasting, about 15 minutes. Add the almonds and raisins and stir fry until everything is slightly softened, toasty, and golden nummy. Set aside.", "name": "Caramelize the onions", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/beef-biryani#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the pan to the stove and melt the remaining 1/2 tablespoon butter and oil over medium high heat. Add the steak pieces &#8211; sear them so that they get nice and browned on all sides, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a plate. Wipe excess grease out of the pan; add the simmer sauce from step one to the pan. While it simmers, measure the spices and add them to the pan. Stir fry until very fragrant, about 3 minutes. Add the yogurt and about 1 cup water and stir until smooth. Add the browned beef back to the pan with the simmer sauce. Cover and simmer gently for 1 hour.", "name": "Make the beef", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/beef-biryani#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the beef is simmering (yum!) soak the rice in cold water and then rinse thoroughly to remove the starch &#8211; this helps it from being too sticky later on. Heat 3 cups of beef broth in a saucepan and bring to a low boil. Add the rinsed rice and simmer, covered, for 5-10 minutes. The rice should be partially cooked but it&#8217;s okay if it&#8217;s still a little raw. It will finish cooking in the oven. Drain off the liquid and set aside. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.", "name": "Prepare the rice", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/beef-biryani#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the rice on top of the beef and make a small well in the middle for moisture. Let stand for 10-15 minutes before fluffing with a fork and serving. I used green salsa in place of the red enchilada sauce and just kind of made a well in it to crack my egg since the salsa was pretty thick. I DID do the crispy cheese edge (yum! And I\u2019m not usually a cheesy egg person) and topped it with pickled onions which I basically always have in my fridge and some baby mixed greens that I just needed to use up. \r\n\r\nSo, yes, I changed the recipe A LOT, but it was still awesome and made for a quick and easy lunch for one. Stir in the bread paste and mix well &#8211; the sauce should start to thicken into a consistency almost like a light gravy or cream sauce. Make the filling and just keep it in the fridge for a couple of days. When you're ready to eat the tacos, spread that filling into the tortillas and fry them up! Easy. OR, alternatively, you can freeze these little cuties! Spread the black bean filling into the tacos, fold them, and then freeze them BEFORE frying. Place the balls in the fridge for 20-30 minutes while you prep everything else. You can even pop it in the freezer for a few minutes &#8211; you just want them to be pretty cold so the butter mixture doesn&#8217;t immediately melt out everywhere once you start cooking them.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/smash-burgers-with-house-sauce#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Butter the buns and toast them on your skillet or griddle until golden.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/smash-burgers-with-house-sauce#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prep the toppings and house sauce (see notes).", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/smash-burgers-with-house-sauce#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut a small piece of parchment paper that you&#8217;ll use on top of the burgers to prevent sticking.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/smash-burgers-with-house-sauce#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat a cast iron skillet or flat griddle until it&#8217;s very hot; place a few of the burgers on the hot surface. They&#8217;ll be super sizzly and splattery, but they should make a nice, round, thin smash burger shape on the griddle. (The ideal tool for this is a cast iron grill press, but a flat spatula can work in a pinch). Cook for a few minutes and then flip and top with cheese right away. Sprinkle the top of each salmon filet with a teaspoon or two of additional sugar/salt mixture. Transfer the pan from the stovetop into the oven. Let the salmon broil for 5-10 minutes, checking occasionally to make sure it&#8217;s not burning. The sugar in the pan might look burnt but that&#8217;s okay as long as the tops of the salmon are looking golden brown. When the salmon is done cooking, remove from the oven and allow to cool for a few minutes (that sugar gets HOT). You should be able to just keep stirring the spinach around for a minute and it will wilt and reduce in size. Transfer to a bowl and set aside. I made them last night on a whim and only had sour cream and fresh blueberries in the fridge instead of yogurt and frozen berries. I added too much batter at the bottom (1.5tbsp), so next time I'm only doing a leveled 1tbsp (this will allow the cream cheese to actually sit at the middle). I also added an extra tbsp of cream cheese to the filling. Be sure to use all the crumbles - I thought I overdid it and omitted half a cup, but noticed I could've added much more after the muffins expanded. Don't overbake!! You'll lose the filling part of the muffin and be stuck with a slight cream cheese taste. These were gone the next morning in the matter of 2 hours!!!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ann"}, "datePublished": "2020-05-02", "reviewBody": "Oh. When making the streusel, the mixture immediately started turning into more of a paste then a crumble. I tried adding more flour but couldn\u2019t bring it back, so I spread the mixture thinly on wax paper and popped in the freezer while I moved onto step two: the cheesecake filling. This step was actually problem free, so I optimistically moved onto the batter. After creaming the butter and sugar (or what I thought was creaming them), I added the eggs and yogurt. The whole mix immediately curdled! I decided not to panic and slowly added some gf flour to see if it would come back together. It appeared to be working so I finished up the batter steps. I took the \u201cstreusel\u201d out of the freezer and broke it up into little bits to sprinkle on top.  \r\n\r\nIn the end, I\u2019d say I\u2019d overfilled the cups and the streusel did not look very pretty, but these are so incredibly delicious, I\u2019m glad I persevered! Slowly add the milk and broth, a little bit at a time, whisking after each addition until you get a nice, smooth, thickened sauce. Season with salt and stir in the wine. You should boil the gnocchi within 30-45 minutes of cutting it up, otherwise they will stick together. And they can stick together even <em>more</em> after cooking, before the sauce is added.<br/><br/>Overall, this is a recipe that's best to make fresh for the best results!", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#faq-question-1695750138906", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#faq-question-1695750138906", "name": "Do I have to use Tipo 00 flour?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "What I love about using Tipo 00 is that it makes the gnocchi SUPER soft and pillowy. Serve it for dinner with sauces and toppings and you've got a party!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "homemade gnocchi, gnocchi recipe, easy gnocchi recipe", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Gnocchi-Feature-1-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Gnocchi-Feature-1-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Gnocchi-Feature-1-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Gnocchi-Feature-1.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi", "recipeIngredient": ["4 russet potatoes (2 1/2 lbs)", "2 1/2 cups flour + 1/2 cup extra for work surfaces as needed (we use DeLallo Tipo 00 flour)", "1 cup ricotta cheese", "1 egg", "1 heaping teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add potatoes to a pot. Cover with water and bring to a boil. Cook for about 20 minutes. Remove from water and let cool on towels to absorb excess moisture.", "name": "Cook Potatoes", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the peels. Grate potatoes finely using a box grater (or, ideally, a potato ricer).", "name": "Peel and Grate Potatoes:\u00a0", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mound potatoes on a clean work surface. Add flour, then ricotta, then egg, then salt. Whisk with a fork, starting in the center and working your way out. It will get crumbly.", "name": "Mix Dough", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use your hands to gently bring the mixture together into a smooth dough. Don&#8217;t overmix it and don&#8217;t overflour it!", "name": "Knead Dough", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/how-to-make-homemade-gnocchi#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Form into a loaf. Cut the loaf into slices. Roll each slice into a rope. A splash of white wine when you're simmering could do the same thing.\r\n\r\n- This is a good pantry, staple kind of a meal\u2026 Except for the bundle of fresh thyme. Who has that sitting around their house? A tablespoon or so of dried Italian herbs or maybe half tablespoon of dried thyme, is an OK substitute. \r\n\r\n- 2 tablespoons of tomato paste is an annoying amount. I use an entire 4 ounce can and that was fine. It's a dragged to have a third of a can of tomato paste sitting around your fridge waiting for the next recipe.\r\n\r\nI used all of the optional add-ins - Grated pecorino, sun-dried tomatoes, and an entire bunch of spinach. They all added some needed color, texture, and flavor."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Anne H"}, "datePublished": "2025-08-03", "reviewBody": "This is great! If making ahead, store in the fridge.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/whole-wheat-french-toast-pear-chutney-mascarpone#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat a nonstick pan or griddle over medium high heat. Cut the slices of bread in half so you have a total of 12 bread pieces. Whisk the egg yolks, half and half, milk, vanilla, and flour until smooth. Dip the bread in the egg mixture and transfer to the hot skillet. Fry for a few minutes on each side until golden brown (I don&#8217;t recommend using butter &#8211; try to use a skillet or griddle that has a very smooth nonstick surface that makes flipping really easy). For each quesadilla, melt 1/2 tablespoon butter in the skillet and layer these ingredients directly in the pan: 1 tortilla, 2 tablespoons cheese, 1/3 cup pepper mushroom mixture, 2 tablespoons cheese, 1 tortilla. By the time you&#8217;ve layered them, the bottom will probably be getting a little golden brown. Press the quesadilla together with the back of a spatula to help it stick and carefully flip it over in the skillet. I usually hold my hand on the top tortilla as I flip it to keep the filling from falling out. Let the quesadilla brown for another 2-3 minutes on the other side, just enough to turn golden brown and melt the cheese. Remove and cut into wedges (and repeat for the other quesadillas). Bring to a low boil and let everything simmer for 5-10 minutes until the sugar has fully dissolved. Pour through a fine mesh strainer to remove the cloves and rogue rosemary leaves. This is not arroz con pollo - Please don\u2019t call it that. Arroz con pollo is originally from the Caribbean islands - we don\u2019t use jalape\u00f1o. The base of the arroz con pollo is using something called sofrito which is made from scratch by blending cilantro, recao, sweet red peppers, onions, garlic (this sofrito or cilantro base is used in the beginning, not at the end like you did). Then using anatto sazon and adobo for the seasoning of the chicken, as well as a bit of cumin and a bit of oregano -(We never use as much cumin as you used) You also put a spoon of tomato sauce or tomato paste. Put a few olives in to cook with the rice, not after. Also, do not put the pot of rice in the oven, it will come out too sticky and watery as I see yours came out - it should be fluffy which just a bit of stickiness - not watery."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Waiter app"}, "datePublished": "2020-10-06", "reviewBody": "looking very tasty, very curious about taste."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Erika"}, "datePublished": "2020-10-06", "reviewBody": "I made this tonight and thought it was delicious and so easy! When you're first starting out, <em>plan to spend $50/year on the lower end to $100/year on the higher end</em>.<br/>2. <strong>Domain</strong> \u2013\u2013 Short, catchy domains typically cost a bit more money (sometimes in the thousands of dollars range!), but most domains that are available these days cost <em>less than $15/year</em>.<br/>3. <strong>Ingredients and/or Meals</strong> \u2013\u2013 Depending on the type of content you publish on your food blog, you'll need to purchase the ingredients (for any recipes you make) and/or meals (for the restaurant reviews you publish). The amounts can vary wildly from blogger to blogger, but this is the cost that you can control the most!<br/><br/>You don't need a fancy DSLR camera or props to start a food blog \u2013\u2013 start with the gear that you have (even if that's just a smart phone!) and upgrade if and when you're ready to.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641229158971", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641229158971", "name": "How can I get paid as a food blogger?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "When you're just starting out, we recommend building up your content<br/><br/>But if you've been publishing high-quality content for a while and are ready to unlock some monetization opportunities, there are a lot of different ways to get started.<br/><br/>The key to maximizing the money you can make as a food blogger is to <em>diversify </em>the ways that you're bringing money in. Some of the most common ways that food bloggers monetize are through <strong>display ads</strong>, <strong>sponsored content</strong>, and <strong>selling products</strong>. <br/><br/>If you're looking for more monetization ideas, <a href=\"https://www.foodbloggerpro.com/hi-poy/\">check out Food Blogger Pro's free ebook, 18 Ways to Monetize a Food Blog</a>!", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641244940671", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641244940671", "name": "How many posts should I have to launch my blog?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This is one of the most common questions we get! We suggest to <em>just</em> <em>launch</em>, and fill out the content later.<br/><br/>Your blog doesn\u2019t need to be 100% perfect and polished in order for you to\u00a0<em>start blogging</em>. Things change in this industry\u00a0<em>a lot</em>, so perfection doesn\u2019t really exist. \ud83d\ude43<br/><br/>But by launching, you\u2019re taking the most important (and most difficult!) step \u2013\u2013 <strong>creating a place all your own on the internet.</strong><br/><br/>Launch your blog and then focus on creating that top-notch content to start building consistency and an audience.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641245106633", "position": 5, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/resources/how-to-start-a-food-blog#faq-question-1641245106633", "name": "How often should I publish a new blog post?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This is an easy one: as often as you can publish <em>high-quality</em> content (if you're a food blogger, that means that your recipes and posts are great, your photos are beautiful, you're answering the questions your readers have, and your post is a helpful piece of content). <br/><br/>You get to choose what's consistent and attainable for you, so take a few weeks to figure out how often you can produce that great content and stick to that schedule.
